title: Fix fetch-latest on arm machines
body: Copied from the modern version of install-rustup, this fixes #52

title: Bump versions of many dependencies
body: Lots of pre-1.0 crates that need bringing up ... various API changes to track, but I think that everything here will be OK.

title: Work around a bug in which `dynfmt` fails in release mode
body:
See: https://github.com/jan-auer/dynfmt/pull/9

And: https://github.com/jqnatividad/qsv/pull/1467/files

This should go away when a new dynfmt release comes out, or at least migrate to a scheme where we're not relying on someone else's repo and branch. But this should be OK for now.

title: Update to fix Zenodo integration, hopefully
body: Based on my local testing, hopefully we only need to tweak a few things.

title: npm: add --yarn option to install-token command
body: Turns out that in order to use `yarn npm publish`, we need to install the token into a different file. But we can use the same token.

title: Some fixes for Yarn-based monorepos
body: Based on porting over wwt-webgl-engine.

title: Experiment with building aarch64-apple-darwin
body: See if we can figure out how to get this going.

title: Address the Windows dirtiness issue
body: Starting out trying to create a debug build to try to nail down these Windows dirtiness issues.

title: Fix Windows install
body: All this time, two out of my three versions of the Windows install snippet have had a typo!

title: zenodo: fix monorepo non-release pathway
body: I overlooked something. If you were making a release in a monorepo, and a Zenodo project was *not* being released, the preregister command would error out. But to be consistent with our pull-request workflow -- and generally more helpful -- we should succeed without minting new DOIs. In principle, we should recover the DOIs from the most recent release and use them, which we could do by tracking down the zenodo.json file in the release branch, but we don't have good infrastructure to do that. So instead we just use the existing fake-DOI approach.

title: ci/zenodo.json5: assign our concept record ID
More stuff to get Zenodo working
body:
My artifact uploads were hitting the 30s timeouts that reqwest has by default, because Zenodo is slow. Local testing indicates that if we just remove the timeouts, things should work.

Some other minor improvements, but that's the big one.

title: Fix release checks
body: `zenodo upload-artifacts` and `zenodo publish` should require that they be run in "release" mode, not "rc" mode.

title: Iterate the CI some more
body: So far so good, but had something dumb that made the deployment workflows not run ... whoopsie!

title: Zenodo touchup
body: Fixes for release.

title: Add Zenodo support
body: I still need to revamp the CI files to actually start using it here, but I think we're close!

title: Add the ability to ignore autodetected projects
body: Done with central configuration based on qnames, which seems like the most robust way to do things. This way if you vendor in some code you can control the Cranko-ification without needing to modify the vendored files.

title: csproj: rewrite ProductCode and PackageCode when rewriting version
body: We were doing this at least somewhat incorrectly: the docs state that no two installers should have the same PackageCode unless they're identical. The ProductCode has more sophisticated semantics that we could and probably should support, but I'm trying to get my installers working and am going to pile up some technical debt here.

title: Fix vdproj rewriting: can't use all four version terms
body: There's always something to fix ...

title: Add some hacky/basic vdproj support
body: I'm not sure whether this is gross or not? But it's meeting a need that I have, and architecturally I think it makes sense.

title: Fix up .NET dev versions and write up some more docs on internal deps
body: Looks like .NET version terms can only go up to 65534: [link](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44679828/reserved-max-value-in-the-net-assembly-version).

title: Add some basic support for Visual Studio C# projects
body: I don't understand this ecosystem well at all, so the support is probably pretty janky, but I think it will meet my needs.
